Endless Idea Generator Ask the following questions: Who am I writing for? So that they can do what? Topic = Therapy For who = Stressed out dads who work in corporate careers So that = They can stop taking their stress out on family
Every Sunday, I write about communication technology in a short, free newsletter that’s easy to understand. It takes less than 10 minutes, and keeps you learning continuously.

Richard Feynman, the Nobel prize winning physicist, once had a visitor in his office - a historian who wanted to interview him.
He invented CAPTCHA but… Manuel Blum - a Turing Award winner - had 3 students who won the Turing Award themselves, apart from others who won Knuth and Godel prizes.
Whenever I run into a hard problem at work, I use the following method to chip away at the problem. It does not always result in a solution, but I definitely make progress.
What is your idea? I want to create a top of the line Electrical Engineering Newsletter on Substack because none exists.

item.title: How amazing you can tell wave properties from circuit elements
item.description: You tell me what the dimensions of the line are, I’ll tell you how fast the signal travels. I’m amazed this can even be calculated.

item.title: How I chose the topic for my newsletter?
item.description: Initial idea was to make it an educational newsletter people cant upskill easily in hard EE fields they need to read difficult text books or watch boring long videos on youtube from professors on blackboard my idea was to write a short piece that people can read easily every sunday create a list of articles categorized by topic that people can refer when needed I also wanted it to be inspirational something that made people excited to take up RF engineering write something that stopped people from losing interest in engineering during their day to day boring job What did I realize from the people who subscribed that most people were students from different parts of the world the other category of people were junior engineers this seemed to make sense considering the educational material i was putting out i was not attracting too many professionals I dont think I have no idea what the demographics are, since I didnt do a survey What was my biggest fear in choosing this niche?

item.title: Measuring Compression with a Power Meter vs using a PNAX
item.description: PNAX measures fundamental RF power in a narrow bandwidth around the tone. As a result, the compression occurs faster than when measuring with a Power Meter, because the power meter usually measures power across a much wider bandwidth.

Why did I start my newsletter as completely free?
item.description: I wanted to provide people as much value as possible through my posts before I started charging people I want enough eyeballs on my content to establish myself as domain authority and build trust with the audience I need to demonstrate consistency (to the audience and myself) that I am capable of delivering a product on a schedule I want people to learn and be inspired from the content.

item.title: William Shockley
item.description: He was silicon valley’s first entrepreneur and also the worst engineering manager ever. These famous people worked for him: Gordon Moore and Robert Noyce (Intel) Walter Brattain and John Bardeen (Nobel prize) Jean Hoerni (inventor of planar process) Jay Last (significant contributions to silicon integrated circuits) Eugene Kleiner (founder of one of the first silicon valley VC firms) He is William Shockley.

item.title: Working on personal projects
item.description: You are not spending as much time on personal projects as you should. Both the company and your skillset will stand to benefit.

item.title: Write down one engineering learning per day
item.description: Here’s a simple way to supercharge your engineering learning. Write down one thing you have learned everyday. You would have learned 30 concepts in a month.
